messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....
messages.msgSnippet: Hello Mr. Hartman, What an absolute treat it was to get receive your e-mail! In this vast internet sea ,  it s great addressing someone directly.  I never had
messages.messageBody:
Hello Mr. Hartman,

What an absolute treat it was to get receive your e-mail!
In this vast "internet sea", it's great addressing someone directly. I
never had a "grandfather" so you be "grandfatherly" all you want. Please do
not apologize for that.

Thank you for the words of encouragement. They have not fallen on deaf ears.
I am very new at this and I have already discovered some valueable lessons.
I just wanted to share that with Kim. It can be frustrating reading of
these e-mails and not really knowing what's being said but it's a "process"
like anything else. The "learning curve" is extremely steep at this point
and there have been a few "nose bleeds", LOL! But like you said, "study,
study, study".

I couldn't agree more with "Nihonto" picking me. LOL! O.K., "Grandfather
lesson # 1", DO NOT SELL MY BOOKS Got it! Thank you

Kind regards, Mark


-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Ron Hartmann
Sent: Wednesday, July 13, 2005 3:12 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....


Hi Mark -

>...maybe I should pick another hobbie! I laugh at it now but it didn't
sit well...

Had to laugh at this comment because we have all experienced this thinking
somewhere along the way. Actually, I doubt that many of us "picked" this
hobby; rather, I think the hobby picked those of us having that "spark,"
that fascination (obsession?) with ancient things needing preserving.

>not having a "ton of money"...

Today, I sometimes wonder how the newer collectors bitten by this interest
survive, seeing the cost of things today. Then I realize that 35 years ago
when swords could be bought for $25, many of us struggled to purchase those
"cheapies." Fresh out of the navy and with a new wife and baby, and making
squat in salary, I had to peddle whatever could be found and then hoard
those dollars for when a sword of interest was found. Fun times, indeed! So
I suppose things never change.

>Whatever you spend on books, you will save when you come to buy your
pieces.

Truer words where never written! My only regrets regarding books are the
books I sold off, thinking I'd never really use them. Buy they better books
as they come out because once they are out-of-print, the price exculates.
Yes, the internet has a wealth of information on it but there is nothing
like researching a sword of kodogu with a good library at your fingertips.
You recommended "educate yourself" and that is the key to advancing in our
area of study. I too was told to "study, study, study" when I met my first
knowledgeable person familiar with Japanese swords (Dr. Thomas Hoopes) back
around 1968.

Sorry...feeling "grandfatherly" today...just had to add my few cents worth
to this discussion.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Mark Jaillet
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, July 12, 2005 9:55 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....


Hi Kim,
As a complete beginner myself, rest assured, there
is
information out there. It will not however fall into your lap. There is
a
ton of information on the web. I do not live in a "Nihonto Knowledge
Rich
Enviroment"! My only contact for information is the web. As far as not
having a "ton of money", I once mentioned the same statement to my very
first contact in the Nihonto world. His reply to me was that maybe I
should
pick another hobbie! I laugh at it now but it didn't sit well with me
when
he first told me. It forced me to re-focus my train of thought. EDUCATE
yourself Kim. Whatever you spend on books, you will save when you come
to
buy your pieces.

Your frustration came across load and clear! As a beginner, I could
relate.
I agree with Barry, we are all busy. Do not think that you are being
intensionally ignored.

Good luck in your quest. Enjoy the journey.......................

Mark




[Mark Jaillet]
-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
[mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Kim Ghobrial
Sent: Friday, July 08, 2005 10:12 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....


Hey all,
I'm not sure what is going on, but every time I send something or
reply
to someone, I don't get any response from anyone. I kind of feel like
I
and my posts are invisible to everyone. The other lists that I'm on,
I
get some type of response from someone, and I don't feel like I'm
ignored. If someone doesn't know, I would like to know this, if I
need
to get Photos let me know, but don't ignore the questions. There are
a
lot of folks on this list which has expertise in parts of swords or
full
swords and then there are folks, like myself which are learning from
asking questions and listening to the answers. I don't have tons of
money for expensive books, what books I do have, do not cover areas
which I'm asking questions about. So, please, if someone asks a
question, please acknowledge it, even if it is an answer like, "I
don't
know the answer."

In the case of the question below, would it help in getting a photo of
the pieces and putting it up on this list for all of you to see?

Sincerely,
Kim

Kim Ghobrial wrote:

>Hi Everyone,
>Sorry to ask this, but I was looking at an Auction, which I'm going
to
>see tomorrow and wanted to know if this is something for me to look
at
>or not. Also, if it is okay, if the estimate of $120.00-180.00 is
okay
>for this piece.
>
>THREE JAPANESE COLLECTIBLES: two sword fittings, Fuchi-kashira
>attributed to the Goto School having "kiku" and "kiri" motifs with
gold
>accents on black field, late Edo-early Meiji Period; together with
>*ivory* carved ojime, inlaid, "Fukuzuke" (good luck) design, signed
by
>the carver, attributed to the Meiji Period.
>
>Kim
>
>
>
>Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Mark - ... Had to laugh at this comment because we have all experienced this thinking somewhere along the way. Actually, I doubt that many of us picked
messages.messageBody:
Hi Mark -

>...maybe I should pick another hobbie! I laugh at it now but it didn't sit well...

Had to laugh at this comment because we have all experienced this thinking somewhere along the way. Actually, I doubt that many of us "picked" this hobby; rather, I think the hobby picked those of us having that "spark," that fascination (obsession?) with ancient things needing preserving.

>not having a "ton of money"...

Today, I sometimes wonder how the newer collectors bitten by this interest survive, seeing the cost of things today. Then I realize that 35 years ago when swords could be bought for $25, many of us struggled to purchase those "cheapies." Fresh out of the navy and with a new wife and baby, and making squat in salary, I had to peddle whatever could be found and then hoard those dollars for when a sword of interest was found. Fun times, indeed! So I suppose things never change.

>Whatever you spend on books, you will save when you come to buy your pieces.

Truer words where never written! My only regrets regarding books are the books I sold off, thinking I'd never really use them. Buy they better books as they come out because once they are out-of-print, the price exculates. Yes, the internet has a wealth of information on it but there is nothing like researching a sword of kodogu with a good library at your fingertips. You recommended "educate yourself" and that is the key to advancing in our area of study. I too was told to "study, study, study" when I met my first knowledgeable person familiar with Japanese swords (Dr. Thomas Hoopes) back around 1968.

Sorry...feeling "grandfatherly" today...just had to add my few cents worth to this discussion.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Mark Jaillet
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, July 12, 2005 9:55 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....


Hi Kim,
As a complete beginner myself, rest assured, there is
information out there. It will not however fall into your lap. There is a
ton of information on the web. I do not live in a "Nihonto Knowledge Rich
Enviroment"! My only contact for information is the web. As far as not
having a "ton of money", I once mentioned the same statement to my very
first contact in the Nihonto world. His reply to me was that maybe I should
pick another hobbie! I laugh at it now but it didn't sit well with me when
he first told me. It forced me to re-focus my train of thought. EDUCATE
yourself Kim. Whatever you spend on books, you will save when you come to
buy your pieces.

Your frustration came across load and clear! As a beginner, I could relate.
I agree with Barry, we are all busy. Do not think that you are being
intensionally ignored.

Good luck in your quest. Enjoy the journey.......................

Mark




[Mark Jaillet]

money for expensive books, what books I do have, do not cover areas

Kim

messages.msgSnippet: Hi Kim, As a complete beginner myself, rest assured, there is information out there. It will not however fall into your lap. There is a ton of information on
messages.messageBody:
Hi Kim,
As a complete beginner myself, rest assured, there is
information out there. It will not however fall into your lap. There is a
ton of information on the web. I do not live in a "Nihonto Knowledge Rich
Enviroment"! My only contact for information is the web. As far as not
having a "ton of money", I once mentioned the same statement to my very
first contact in the Nihonto world. His reply to me was that maybe I should
pick another hobbie! I laugh at it now but it didn't sit well with me when
he first told me. It forced me to re-focus my train of thought. EDUCATE
yourself Kim. Whatever you spend on books, you will save when you come to
buy your pieces.

Your frustration came across load and clear! As a beginner, I could relate.
I agree with Barry, we are all busy. Do not think that you are being
intensionally ignored.

Good luck in your quest. Enjoy the journey.......................

Mark

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....
messages.msgSnippet: Wow, thank you David.  That was really interesting.  I ve bookmarked that website. Kim
messages.messageBody:
Wow, thank you David. That was really interesting. I've bookmarked
that website.

Kim

David Zincavage wrote:

>An ojime is the bead between the inro and the netsuke. See:
>
>http://www.asianartmall.com/ojimearticle.htm
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Kim Ghobrial
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Friday, July 08, 2005 6:53 PM
> Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....
>
>
> Okay, no problem. I didn't know in the description that they had a
> Netsuke included. I didn't go tonight, so I will be bringing my camera
> tomorrow to take photos of the item(s).
>
> Thank you,
> Kim
>
> David Zincavage wrote:
>
> >It is impossible to judge the merit or value of items being auctioned from a description of this sort. If the fuchi kashira really were Goto, they'd probably be worth more than the estimates, but lots of black and gold Goto-esque kodogu of many levels of quality were produced. Ojime are netsuke/inro-related, not Nihonto-related.
> >
> >
> > ----- Original Message -----

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Curran, I have no clue to what I m going to be looking at, that is why I will take photos tomorrow.  If it is a fake, I can let them know too. Kim
messages.messageBody:
Hi Curran,
I have no clue to what I'm going to be looking at, that is why I will
take photos tomorrow. If it is a fake, I can let them know too.

Kim

Curran Campbell wrote:

>Kim,
>
>Post photos.
>Beware of the 'Goto-esque'.
>It gets abused so much that it is not far from pouring
>some paint on canvas, putting my boot imprint into it
>and calling it 'Impressionistic'.
>
>Curran
>
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Barry, I have a Pentax OptioS50 with Museum Settings.  I take photos of Greek and Roman coins up close.  I shouldn t have too much problems.  I will
messages.messageBody:
Hi Barry,
I have a Pentax OptioS50 with Museum Settings. I take photos of Greek
and Roman coins up close. I shouldn't have too much problems. I will
probably take a White sheet of paper to set the item on. I use
PhotoShop LE for cropping, sizing, and Adjusting. I will double check
the photos when I'm there and at least I have Sunday to go back and take
more photos. Tuesday is when it will go up for Auction.

Thank you all,
Kim

Barry Thomas wrote:

>Kim,
>Hope you don't mind a tip or ten!! This advice is based on the assumption that
>you are going to use a digital camera.
>- Use the highest resolution your camera is capable of.
>- Study the User Manual for a CLOSEUP option use if your camera has the
>function.
>- Get AS MUCH of the object you want in the image (LCDscreen or viewfinder)
>before taking the pic. This gives you more pixels on what you want people to
>see.
>- Take as many pics as you can from different angles and distances. It is no
>joy to get home and find all your images (or the otherwise best ones) are out of
>focus or have reflections off a glass case (the camera always sees what the eye
>does not!!).
>- Find out how to increase the exposure of your camera if it has the function.
>Take extra images at +0.5, +1.0 or even +1.5 if the lighting is not bright
>enough.
>- Unload and carefully view all images with an image view application. I use a
>rather simple program called Microsoft PhotoEditor. It is basic but allows
>viewing at up to 400x but I hardly use any more than 150x - if your image is
>beginning to pixellate at 125x then it doesn't have enough resolution.
>- PhotoEditor allows one to rotate and crop images for best presentation and
>viewing so people can concentrate on what you want them to see.
>- Preserve the original images by renaming any image you manipulate with a
>meaningful name. Resave at the highest resolution possible - the jpeg save
>option in PhotoEditor, for example, should be at 100% to preserve image quality.
>- I'm a rank amatuer, but if you're a professional photographer I apologise for
>the imposition...
>
>Finally, don't post large file sizes to the list. Put them on a hosting site
>somewhere.
>
>Reply off-line if I can be of further assistance.
>
>Best regards,
>
>Barry Thomas.
>
>----- Original Message -----
>From: "Kim Ghobrial" <imports@...>
>To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
>Sent: Saturday, July 09, 2005 11:53 AM
>Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....
>
>
>Hi Barry,
>Thank you, I'll take some photos tomorrow and post them for everyone to see.
>
>Kim
>
>
>
>
>Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....
messages.msgSnippet: Kim, Hope you don t mind a tip or ten!!  This advice is based on the assumption that you are going to use a digital camera. - Use the highest resolution your
messages.messageBody:
Kim,
Hope you don't mind a tip or ten!! This advice is based on the assumption that
you are going to use a digital camera.
- Use the highest resolution your camera is capable of.
- Study the User Manual for a CLOSEUP option use if your camera has the
function.
- Get AS MUCH of the object you want in the image (LCDscreen or viewfinder)
before taking the pic. This gives you more pixels on what you want people to
see.
- Take as many pics as you can from different angles and distances. It is no
joy to get home and find all your images (or the otherwise best ones) are out of
focus or have reflections off a glass case (the camera always sees what the eye
does not!!).
- Find out how to increase the exposure of your camera if it has the function.
Take extra images at +0.5, +1.0 or even +1.5 if the lighting is not bright
enough.
- Unload and carefully view all images with an image view application. I use a
rather simple program called Microsoft PhotoEditor. It is basic but allows
viewing at up to 400x but I hardly use any more than 150x - if your image is
beginning to pixellate at 125x then it doesn't have enough resolution.
- PhotoEditor allows one to rotate and crop images for best presentation and
viewing so people can concentrate on what you want them to see.
- Preserve the original images by renaming any image you manipulate with a
meaningful name. Resave at the highest resolution possible - the jpeg save
option in PhotoEditor, for example, should be at 100% to preserve image quality.
- I'm a rank amatuer, but if you're a professional photographer I apologise for
the imposition...

Finally, don't post large file sizes to the list. Put them on a hosting site
somewhere.

Reply off-line if I can be of further assistance.

Best regards,

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: "Kim Ghobrial" <imports@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Saturday, July 09, 2005 11:53 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....


Hi Barry,
Thank you, I'll take some photos tomorrow and post them for everyone to see.

Kim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....
messages.msgSnippet: Kim, Post photos. Beware of the Goto-esque . It gets abused so much that it is not far from pouring some paint on canvas, putting my boot imprint into it and
messages.messageBody:
Kim,

Post photos.
Beware of the 'Goto-esque'.
It gets abused so much that it is not far from pouring
some paint on canvas, putting my boot imprint into it
and calling it 'Impressionistic'.

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....
messages.msgSnippet: Kim, I m sure we re all alive and well on this list, but perhaps a statistical clump means we are all busy at something else in this instant of time... I
messages.messageBody:
Kim,

I'm sure we're all alive and well on this list, but perhaps a "statistical
clump" means we are all busy at something else in this instant of time...

I remember well the pepper keeness of my beginning days (or should that be
"daze"!!!), but one thing I have learnt over time is that it is near-impossible
to assess blades from photos. My maxim is not to buy anything I cannot hold in
my hand and judge for myself. There are far too many subtleties to do otherwise
on my very limited budget. If I were a rich man it would be a slightly
different story, but that's the way of the world. Fittings are a little better
judged from GOOD photos, but from a description such as yours one can only
comment in the most general of terms in essay format, which in practice amount
to nothing that would really help you. The best way to learn is to buy and make
mistakes - you WILL make mistakes, I can guarantee that. So, yes, please give a
link to what you seek an opinion on.

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: "Kim Ghobrial" <imports@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Saturday, July 09, 2005 11:11 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....


Hey all,
I'm not sure what is going on, but every time I send something or reply
to someone, I don't get any response from anyone. I kind of feel like I
and my posts are invisible to everyone. The other lists that I'm on, I
get some type of response from someone, and I don't feel like I'm
ignored. If someone doesn't know, I would like to know this, if I need
to get Photos let me know, but don't ignore the questions. There are a
lot of folks on this list which has expertise in parts of swords or full
swords and then there are folks, like myself which are learning from
asking questions and listening to the answers. I don't have tons of
money for expensive books, what books I do have, do not cover areas
which I'm asking questions about. So, please, if someone asks a
question, please acknowledge it, even if it is an answer like, "I don't
know the answer."

In the case of the question below, would it help in getting a photo of
the pieces and putting it up on this list for all of you to see?

Sincerely,
Kim

Kim Ghobrial wrote:

>Hi Everyone,
>Sorry to ask this, but I was looking at an Auction, which I'm going to
>see tomorrow and wanted to know if this is something for me to look at
>or not. Also, if it is okay, if the estimate of $120.00-180.00 is okay
>for this piece.
>
>THREE JAPANESE COLLECTIBLES: two sword fittings, Fuchi-kashira
>attributed to the Goto School having "kiku" and "kiri" motifs with gold
>accents on black field, late Edo-early Meiji Period; together with
>*ivory* carved ojime, inlaid, "Fukuzuke" (good luck) design, signed by
>the carver, attributed to the Meiji Period.
>
>Kim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] RE: Question....
messages.msgSnippet: It is impossible to judge the merit or value of items being auctioned from a description of this sort.  If the fuchi kashira really were Goto, they d probably
messages.messageBody:
It is impossible to judge the merit or value of items being auctioned from a description of this sort. If the fuchi kashira really were Goto, they'd probably be worth more than the estimates, but lots of black and gold Goto-esque kodogu of many levels of quality were produced. Ojime are netsuke/inro-related, not Nihonto-related.

From: Kim Ghobrial
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

ignored. If someone doesn't know, I would like to know this, if I need
to get Photos let me know, but don't ignore the questions. There are a
lot of folks on this list which has expertise in parts of swords or full
swords and then there are folks, like myself which are learning from
asking questions and listening to the answers. I don't have tons of
money for expensive books, what books I do have, do not cover areas
which I'm asking questions about. So, please, if someone asks a
question, please acknowledge it, even if it is an answer like, "I don't
know the answer."

In the case of the question below, would it help in getting a photo of
the pieces and putting it up on this list for all of you to see?

Sincerely,
Kim

Hey all,
I'm not sure what is going on, but every time I send something or reply
to someone, I don't get any response from anyone. I kind of feel like I
and my posts are invisible to everyone. The other lists that I'm on, I
get some type of response from someone, and I don't feel like I'm
ignored. If someone doesn't know, I would like to know this, if I need
to get Photos let me know, but don't ignore the questions. There are a
lot of folks on this list which has expertise in parts of swords or full
swords and then there are folks, like myself which are learning from
asking questions and listening to the answers. I don't have tons of
money for expensive books, what books I do have, do not cover areas
which I'm asking questions about. So, please, if someone asks a
question, please acknowledge it, even if it is an answer like, "I don't
know the answer."

In the case of the question below, would it help in getting a photo of
the pieces and putting it up on this list for all of you to see?

Sincerely,
Kim

messages.subject: RE: Question....
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Everyone, Sorry to ask this, but I was looking at an Auction, which I m going to see tomorrow and wanted to know if this is something for me to look at or
messages.messageBody:
Hi Everyone,
Sorry to ask this, but I was looking at an Auction, which I'm going to
see tomorrow and wanted to know if this is something for me to look at
or not. Also, if it is okay, if the estimate of $120.00-180.00 is okay
for this piece.

THREE JAPANESE COLLECTIBLES: two sword fittings, Fuchi-kashira
attributed to the Goto School having "kiku" and "kiri" motifs with gold
accents on black field, late Edo-early Meiji Period; together with
*ivory* carved ojime, inlaid, "Fukuzuke" (good luck) design, signed by
the carver, attributed to the Meiji Period.

Kim
